trans-unit.source: Azure AD .NET Getting Started | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure AD .NET Getting Started | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to build a .NET MVC Web API that integrates with Azure AD for authentication and authorization.
trans-unit.target: How to build a .NET MVC Web API that integrates with Azure AD for authentication and authorization.

trans-unit.source: Protect a Web API using Bearer tokens from Azure AD
trans-unit.target: Protect a Web API using Bearer tokens from Azure AD

trans-unit.source: If you’re building an application that provides access to protected resources you will need to know how to protect those resources from unwarranted access.
trans-unit.target: If you’re building an application that provides access to protected resources you will need to know how to protect those resources from unwarranted access.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD makes it simple and straightforward to protect a web API using OAuth Bearer 2.0 Access Tokens with only a few lines of code.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD makes it simple and straightforward to protect a web API using OAuth Bearer 2.0 Access Tokens with only a few lines of code.

trans-unit.source: In Asp.NET web apps, you can accomplish this using Microsoft’s implementation of the community-driven OWIN middleware included in .NET Framework 4.5.
trans-unit.target: In Asp.NET web apps, you can accomplish this using Microsoft’s implementation of the community-driven OWIN middleware included in .NET Framework 4.5.

trans-unit.source: Here we’ll use OWIN to build a "To Do List" web API that:
trans-unit.target: Here we’ll use OWIN to build a "To Do List" web API that:

trans-unit.source: Designates which API's are protected.
trans-unit.target: Designates which API's are protected.

trans-unit.source: Validates that the Web API calls contain a valid Access Token.
trans-unit.target: Validates that the Web API calls contain a valid Access Token.

trans-unit.source: In order to do this, you’ll need to:
trans-unit.target: In order to do this, you’ll need to:

trans-unit.source: Register an application with Azure AD
trans-unit.target: Register an application with Azure AD

trans-unit.source: Set up your app to use the OWIN authentication pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Set up your app to use the OWIN authentication pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Configure a client application to call the To Do List Web API
trans-unit.target: Configure a client application to call the To Do List Web API

trans-unit.source: To get started, <link><linkText>download the app skeleton</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>download the completed sample</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To get started, <link><linkText>download the app skeleton</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>download the completed sample</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Each is a Visual Studio 2013 solution.
trans-unit.target: Each is a Visual Studio 2013 solution.

trans-unit.source: You'll also need an Azure AD tenant in which to register your application.
trans-unit.target: You'll also need an Azure AD tenant in which to register your application.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have one already, <link><linkText>learn how to get one</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have one already, <link><linkText>learn how to get one</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: 1. Register an Application with Azure AD
trans-unit.target: 1. Register an Application with Azure AD

trans-unit.source: To secure your application, you’ll first need to create an application in your tenant and provide Azure AD with a few key pieces of information.
trans-unit.target: To secure your application, you’ll first need to create an application in your tenant and provide Azure AD with a few key pieces of information.

trans-unit.source: Sign into the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Sign into the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: In the left hand nav, click on Active Directory
trans-unit.target: In the left hand nav, click on Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Select a tenant in which to register the application.
trans-unit.target: Select a tenant in which to register the application.

trans-unit.source: Click the Applications tab, and click Add in the bottom drawer.
trans-unit.target: Click the Applications tab, and click Add in the bottom drawer.

trans-unit.source: Follow the prompts and create a new Web Application and/or WebAPI.
trans-unit.target: Follow the prompts and create a new Web Application and/or WebAPI.

trans-unit.source: The Name of the application will describe your application to end-users.
trans-unit.target: The Name of the application will describe your application to end-users.

trans-unit.source: Enter "To Do List Service".
trans-unit.target: Enter "To Do List Service".

trans-unit.source: The Redirect Uri is a scheme and string combination that Azure AD would use to return any tokens your app requested.
trans-unit.target: The Redirect Uri is a scheme and string combination that Azure AD would use to return any tokens your app requested.

trans-unit.source: Enter https://localhost:44321/ for this value.
trans-unit.target: Enter https://localhost:44321/ for this value.

trans-unit.source: Once you’ve completed registration, navigate to Configure tab and locate the App ID URI field.
trans-unit.target: Once you’ve completed registration, navigate to Configure tab and locate the App ID URI field.

trans-unit.source: Enter a tenant-specific identifier for this value, e.g. https://contoso.onmicrosoft.com/TodoListService
trans-unit.target: Enter a tenant-specific identifier for this value, e.g. https://contoso.onmicrosoft.com/TodoListService

trans-unit.source: Save the configuration.
trans-unit.target: Save the configuration.

trans-unit.source: Leave the portal open - you'll also need to register your client application shortly.
trans-unit.target: Leave the portal open - you'll also need to register your client application shortly.

trans-unit.source: 2. Set up your app to use the OWIN authentication pipeline
trans-unit.target: 2. Set up your app to use the OWIN authentication pipeline

trans-unit.source: Now that you’ve registered an application with Azure AD, you need to set up your application to communicate with Azure AD in order to validate incoming requests & tokens.
trans-unit.target: Now that you’ve registered an application with Azure AD, you need to set up your application to communicate with Azure AD in order to validate incoming requests & tokens.

trans-unit.source: To begin, open the solution and add the OWIN middleware NuGet packages to the TodoListService project using the Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: To begin, open the solution and add the OWIN middleware NuGet packages to the TodoListService project using the Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: Add an OWIN Startup class to the TodoListService project called Startup.cs.
trans-unit.target: Add an OWIN Startup class to the TodoListService project called Startup.cs.

trans-unit.source: Right click on the project --> Add --> New Item --> Search for “OWIN”.
trans-unit.target: Right click on the project --> Add --> New Item --> Search for “OWIN”.

trans-unit.source: The OWIN middleware will invoke the Configuration(…) method when your app starts.
trans-unit.target: The OWIN middleware will invoke the Configuration(…) method when your app starts.

trans-unit.source: Change the class declaration to public partial class Startup - we’ve already implemented part of this class for you in another file.
trans-unit.target: Change the class declaration to public partial class Startup - we’ve already implemented part of this class for you in another file.

trans-unit.source: In the Configuration(…) method, make a call to ConfgureAuth(…)
trans-unit.target: In the Configuration(…) method, make a call to ConfgureAuth(…)

trans-unit.source: to set up authentication for your web app.
trans-unit.target: to set up authentication for your web app.

trans-unit.source: Open the file App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs and implement the ConfigureAuth(…) method.
trans-unit.target: Open the file App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs and implement the ConfigureAuth(…) method.

trans-unit.source: The parameters you provide in WindowsAzureActiveDirectoryBearerAuthenticationOptions will serve as coordinates for your app to communicate with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: The parameters you provide in WindowsAzureActiveDirectoryBearerAuthenticationOptions will serve as coordinates for your app to communicate with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Now you can use [Authorize] attributes to protect your controllers and actions with JWT bearer authentication.
trans-unit.target: Now you can use [Authorize] attributes to protect your controllers and actions with JWT bearer authentication.

trans-unit.source: Decorate the Controllers\TodoListController.cs class with an authorize tag.
trans-unit.target: Decorate the Controllers\TodoListController.cs class with an authorize tag.

trans-unit.source: This will force the user to sign in before accessing that page.
trans-unit.target: This will force the user to sign in before accessing that page.

trans-unit.source: When an authorized caller successfully invokes one of the TodoListController APIs, the action might need access to information about the caller.
trans-unit.target: When an authorized caller successfully invokes one of the TodoListController APIs, the action might need access to information about the caller.

trans-unit.source: OWIN provides access to the claims inside the bearer token via the ClaimsPrincpal object.
trans-unit.target: OWIN provides access to the claims inside the bearer token via the ClaimsPrincpal object.

trans-unit.source: A common requirement for web APIs is to validate the "scopes" present in the token - this ensures that the end user has consented to the permissions required to access the Todo List Service:
trans-unit.target: A common requirement for web APIs is to validate the "scopes" present in the token - this ensures that the end user has consented to the permissions required to access the Todo List Service:

trans-unit.source: Finally, open the web.config file in the root of the TodoListService project, and enter your configuration values in the section.
trans-unit.target: Finally, open the web.config file in the root of the TodoListService project, and enter your configuration values in the section.

trans-unit.source: The ida:Tenant is the name of your Azure AD tenant, e.g. "contoso.onmicrosoft.com".
trans-unit.target: The ida:Tenant is the name of your Azure AD tenant, e.g. "contoso.onmicrosoft.com".

trans-unit.source: Your ida:Audience is the App ID URI of the application that you entered in the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: Your ida:Audience is the App ID URI of the application that you entered in the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: 3. Configure a client application & Run the service
trans-unit.target: 3. Configure a client application & Run the service

trans-unit.source: Before you can see the Todo List Service in action, you need to configure the Todo List Client so it can get tokens from AAD and make calls to the service.
trans-unit.target: Before you can see the Todo List Service in action, you need to configure the Todo List Client so it can get tokens from AAD and make calls to the service.

trans-unit.source: Navigate back to the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Navigate back to the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Create a new application in your Azure AD tenant, and select Native Client Application in the resulting prompt.
trans-unit.target: Create a new application in your Azure AD tenant, and select Native Client Application in the resulting prompt.

trans-unit.source: The Name of the application will describe your application to end-users
trans-unit.target: The Name of the application will describe your application to end-users

trans-unit.source: Enter http://TodoListClient/ for the Redirect Uri value.
trans-unit.target: Enter http://TodoListClient/ for the Redirect Uri value.

trans-unit.source: Once you’ve completed registration, AAD will assign your app a unique App Id.
trans-unit.target: Once you’ve completed registration, AAD will assign your app a unique App Id.

trans-unit.source: You’ll need this value in the next steps, so copy it from the Configure tab.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need this value in the next steps, so copy it from the Configure tab.

trans-unit.source: Once you’ve completed registration, navigate to Configure tab and locate the App ID URI field.
trans-unit.target: Once you’ve completed registration, navigate to Configure tab and locate the App ID URI field.

trans-unit.source: Enter a tenant-specific identifier for this value, e.g. https://contoso.onmicrosoft.com/TodoListService
trans-unit.target: Enter a tenant-specific identifier for this value, e.g. https://contoso.onmicrosoft.com/TodoListService

trans-unit.source: Also in Configure tab, locate the "Permissions to Other Applications" section. Click "Add Application." Select "Other" in the "Show" dropdown, and click the upper check mark. Locate & click on your To Do List Service, and click the bottom check mark to add the application. Select "Access To Do List Service" from the "Delegated Permissions" dropdown, and save the configuration.
trans-unit.target: Also in Configure tab, locate the "Permissions to Other Applications" section. Click "Add Application." Select "Other" in the "Show" dropdown, and click the upper check mark. Locate & click on your To Do List Service, and click the bottom check mark to add the application. Select "Access To Do List Service" from the "Delegated Permissions" dropdown, and save the configuration.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open App.config in the TodoListClient project and enter your configuration values in the section.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open App.config in the TodoListClient project and enter your configuration values in the section.

trans-unit.source: The ida:Tenant is the name of your Azure AD tenant, e.g. "contoso.onmicrosoft.com".
trans-unit.target: The ida:Tenant is the name of your Azure AD tenant, e.g. "contoso.onmicrosoft.com".

trans-unit.source: Your ida:ClientId app ID you copied from the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: Your ida:ClientId app ID you copied from the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Your todo:TodoListResourceId is the App ID URI of the To Do List Service application that you entered in the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: Your todo:TodoListResourceId is the App ID URI of the To Do List Service application that you entered in the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Finally, clean, build and run each project!
trans-unit.target: Finally, clean, build and run each project!

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t already, now is the time to create a new user in your tenant with a *.onmicrosoft.com domain.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t already, now is the time to create a new user in your tenant with a *.onmicrosoft.com domain.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the To Do List client with that user, and add some tasks to the user's To Do List.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the To Do List client with that user, and add some tasks to the user's To Do List.

trans-unit.source: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) is provided <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) is provided <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You can now move on to more additional identity scenarios You may want to try:
trans-unit.target: You can now move on to more additional identity scenarios You may want to try:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Build a .NET Native Client with Azure AD >></linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Build a .NET Native Client with Azure AD >></linkText><title></title></link>
